According to the Kerio Control knowledge base regarding crash analysis (Analyzing Kerio Control crashes [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/116226]), crash dumps and support information are used to diagnose the underlying software or configuration issues that may result in service failure. The introduction of the Watchdog feature (as described here: Watchdog Features in Kerio Control [https://support.keriocontrol.gfi.com/article/123562]) is specifically designed to detect service irregularities, automatically restart affected services, and generate crash dumps for further review. This automated recovery helps minimize downtime but does not always address the root cause if it is unresolved at the software or configuration level.

In circumstances like yours, where several patches have been applied and system configuration is stable, but periodic service restarts persist, the most probable explanations are either an unaddressed software defect (which patches may eventually resolve) or site-specific configuration or environmental factors that differ from your other installations. Patch 3 includes multiple stability improvements and bug fixes—if your logs and dumps correspond to an issue directly addressed by the latest patch, then further incidents should be mitigated post-update. If the problem recurs with patch 3 in place, it would indicate either an unresolved defect or an external factor not covered by those updates.

Both outline the diagnostic approach and the effect of recent patches and recovery mechanisms.

If patch 3 resolves the instability, no further customer action should be required. Otherwise, persistence of the problem would indicate a defect or condition that may need to be escalated through your Kerio Control provider for engineering investigation, using the evidence and logs gathered so far.
